title: Energy Up as Oil Futures Rise Most in 10 Years — Energy Roundup
text:
Shares of energy companies rallied alongside oil futures after an attack on Saudi Arabian oilfield infrastructure Saturday knocked as much as 5% of global oil production off-line.

Oil futures posted their biggest daily increase since January 2009 in New York trading, adding 15% to trade near $63 a barrel.

Iran was the staging post for the attacks on Saudi oil facilities, American intelligence informed Saudi allies on Monday, a finding that could prompt a coordinated military response from Saudi Arabia and the U.S. President Donald Trump said the U.S. was prepared to go to war "if we have to go that way" after the attack on Saudi Arabia.

The attack on the oilfields were a "historically large disruption on critical oil infrastructure," said analysts at brokerage Goldman Sachs, as reported earlier. Even a week's outage of affected supplies could add $3-$5 per barrel of a risk premium, while anything beyond six weeks could drive the London Brent contract above $75 a barrel, the analysts said.

Saudi Arabian officials are weighing Aramco's initial public offering, after the attacks on the company's largest oil facilities, The Wall Street Journal reported.

In response to potential shortages caused by the attacks, President Donald Trump provided some relief late Sunday by authorizing the release of oil from the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve if needed to stabilize energy markets.

Shale-oilfield drillers including Pioneer Natural Resources and Continental Resources, rallied as executives indicated to The Wall Street Journal they would maintain, but not lift, production in the wake of the attacks.
